summary: ZIKV is a member of the Flaviviridae family with a positive-sense RNA genome of about 10 kb. it expresses a single polypeptide which is proteolytically processed into 3 structural (C, prM, and E) and 7 nonstructural (NS1, NS2A, NS2B, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, and NS5) proteins. since its discovery in 1947 (3), ZIKV innate immunity is thought to govern both viral replication and pathogenesis. innate antiviral effectors, such as type I and type III interferons, are capable of suppressing ZIKV replication. aberrant activation of innate immunity also results in inflammation, apoptosis, and autophagy. KV NS5 protein was recently shown to suppress type I IFN signaling by targeting STAT2 for degradation (33, 34).
